metadata./Title: Dramatic improvement of drug-resistant epilepsy following cerebral infarction: a case report

sections.Background:
Background An estimated 30% of patients with epilepsy experience drug‑resistant epilepsy, which is the failure 
to control seizures despite the use of two or more antiseizure medications. Although other treatment options are con‑
sidered, these alternatives often prove ineffective.
sections.Case Presentation:
Case presentation A 60‑ year ‑old East Asian male patient diagnosed with drug‑resistant epilepsy experienced sev‑
eral seizures daily despite being on eight different antiseizure medications. Seizures began at age 15. He underwent 
epilepsy surgery at age 34, yet the seizures persisted. An electroencephalogram revealed multifocal sharp waves 
in the left hemisphere. Cerebral hemorrhages at ages 47, 50, and 56 were caused by head trauma during seizures. 
The patient became wheelchair ‑bound and now resides in a nursing home. At age 58, after suffering an acute cer ‑
ebral infarction due to occlusion of the left internal carotid artery, his daily seizures ceased entirely. Despite remain‑
ing wheelchair ‑bound, he did not experience a significant decline in his quality of life. The cessation of seizures 
has reduced his risk of further trauma, and he has remained seizure ‑free for 3 years on just one antiseizure medication.
sections.Conclusion:
Conclusion Surgical treatments for epilepsy often fail, with insufficient resection being a leading cause of these fail‑
ures. In some cases, extensive destruction from an ischemic stroke may be beneficial. Furthermore, this case suggests 
that infarction therapy could be a potential treatment for patients with drug‑resistant epilepsy.
Keywords  Drug‑resistant epilepsy, Cerebral infarction, Therapeutics
Background
Drug-resistant epilepsy is defined as the failure to con trol seizures despite the use of two or more appropriate 
antiseizure medications. An estimated 30% of all patients 
with epilepsy have drug-resistant epilepsy. Epilepsy 
can develop secondary to various mechanisms after a 
stroke, and one study found that 6.4% of stroke patients developed epilepsy [1]. We report a case of a patient with 
drug-resistant epilepsy who achieved seizure freedom 
after a cerebral infarction.
Case presentation
A 60-year-old East Asian male patient is being fol lowed up in our neurology outpatient department for 
drug-resistant epilepsy. He has a history of status epi lepticus following a fall while riding a bicycle at age 15, 
after which he started antiseizure medication. Due to 
poor seizure control, he underwent epilepsy surgery at 
another hospital when he was 34  years old, though the 
specific type of surgery performed remains unclear. The 
patient exhibited two types of seizure semiology: focal 
myoclonic seizures in his right arm and focal to bilateral Open Access

tonic–clonic seizures. Despite surgery, his seizures 
remained uncontrolled and occurred several times a day, 
even with antiseizure medication polytherapy, including 
levetiracetam (1000  mg twice daily), valproate (500  mg 
twice daily), oxcarbazepine (450  mg twice daily), zon isamide (200 mg twice daily), topiramate (100 mg twice 
daily), lacosamide (50  mg twice daily), clobazam (5  mg 
twice daily), and clonazepam (0.5  mg once daily). Rou tine electroencephalography revealed frequent multifocal 
sharp waves in the left hemisphere, along with consist ently observed theta slow waves throughout the left hem isphere (Fig.  1). At ages 47, 50, and 56, he suffered acute 
cerebral hemorrhages due to seizure-related trauma, 
which led to him becoming wheelchair-bound and reside 
in a nursing home. After the third cerebral hemorrhage, 
he began tapering off his antiseizure medications due to 
a very poor response. Interestingly, no increase in seizure 
frequency was observed during the tapering process. He 
was subsequently maintained on three medications: lev etiracetam (1500  mg twice daily), topiramate (100  mg 
twice daily), and lacosamide (100 mg twice daily). At age 
58, he experienced an acute cerebral infarction due to 
occlusion of the left internal carotid artery. Encephaloma lacic changes in the left parieto-occipital area expanded 
to encompass the entire left cerebral hemisphere after the 
ischemic cerebral infarction (Fig.  2). After the ischemic 
stroke, his daily recurrent seizures completely ceased, 
and he was able to maintain a wheelchair-bound lifestyle. 
Before the stroke, frequent seizures had caused difficulty 
with speaking, which made it challenging to assess how 
much his speech impairment after the stroke affected his 
daily life. However, seizure freedom has reduced his risk of repeated trauma and improved his overall quality of 
life. He has remained seizure-free for more than 3 years 
while taking only one medication: lacosamide (100  mg 
twice daily).
sections.Discussion:
Discussion and conclusions
This case describes a patient with drug-resistant epilepsy 
whose seizures persisted despite polytherapy and surgi cal intervention, but who achieved complete seizure free dom following an incidental cerebral infarction. Several 
reports have documented spontaneous improvement in 
tremor among patients with Parkinson’s disease following 
a stroke. These reports suggest that damage to anatomi cal areas associated with the symptoms may contribute 
to this improvement [2–4]. However, to our knowledge, 
there are no reports of intractable seizures disappearing 
following a cerebral infarction.
The patient’s brain lesion likely originated from a fall 
while riding a bike at age 15. Over time, the epileptogenic 
circuitry may have developed into a robust and complex 
network, involving a wide range of brain areas. Previ ously, it was believed that epileptogenesis was complete 
after the latent period—the interval between brain injury 
and the onset of the first clinical seizure—and that the 
probability of seizures would remain constant thereaf ter. However, observations suggest that the frequency 
and severity of seizures may gradually increase over time 
after a brain injury. This suggests that the process of epi leptogenesis may continue beyond the latent period [5, 
6]. Given that the surgery was performed 20 years after 
the initial brain insult, it is possible that not all of the 
patient’s epileptogenic lesions were removed. This could

be due to the unclear delineation of epileptogenic lesions 
and the technical limitations of surgical techniques avail able in the mid-1990s.
After a stroke, secondary epilepsy can develop due to 
factors such as neural inflammation, glial scar formation, 
and alterations in neural connectivity [7]. The sudden 
cessation of habitual seizures following the cerebral 
infarction is likely due to the extensive destruction of 
the epileptogenic zone, including residual epileptogenic 
lesions. The maintenance of seizure-free status for 
more than 3 years after the infarction may be attributed 
to the concurrent destruction of normal brain tissue 
surrounding the epileptogenic lesion, which could have 
prevented the development of new seizure foci. Unlike 
surgery, where brain tissue is resected along macroscopic 
boundaries, cerebral infarction affects areas along the 
vasculature that are difficult to physically delineate. 
Paradoxically, this suggests that the lesions were 
effectively “removed” by the infarction process. Infarction 
therapy, which aims to remove tumors by occluding 
their blood supply and cutting off nutrients and oxygen, 
has shown promise in certain cancer treatments [8–10]. 
The complete resolution of our patient’s daily recurrent 
seizures following an accidental cerebral infarction 
prompts us to envision potential paradigm shifts in the 
treatment of drug-resistant epilepsy. This case raises 
the possibility that carefully planned induced cerebral 
infarction could serve as an alternative treatment option 
for drug-resistant epilepsy. However, since cerebral 
infarction can be a risk factor for developing epilepsy, it is 
crucial to carefully select appropriate patients.
